Read in English

March 31 is Beowulf's birthday and of course I couldn't let such an important date slip by without proper commemoration. At first, I was struggling a lot trying to think of what to do. I didn't want to just make Beowulf in a cool pose or something like that, I've already done that last year.

After banging my head against my desk a few times, I decided that I wanted to be a little more ambitious. It would be a risky move, considering that I would have around 2 weeks to work on it. But I guess I can't learn from my mistakes. :eggbug:

Once I decided that I wanted to make a full-ass illustration, I started brainstorming some ideas. I wanted a warm and intimate scene, and a wrestling arena doesn't necessarily falls into that description... (even though I have some ideas based on Beowulf's empty stage). I considered the arena's backstage, but that wouldn't work either. A locker room is also off consideration, unless I were to draw him being [THIS SECTION WAS REMOVED BY THE COHOST STAFF].

In Beowulf's Story Mode, when not fighting, he has an acting career, so an actor's dressing room wouldn't be a strange scenery for him. Now, drawing him alone in his own room would be kinda sad... So I decided to make a sort of private party between him and Annie, his friend and coworker.

The Process

This artwork is probably the one I put most thought on. I gathered a lot of references, I studied composition and perspective, later on planned my values, and tried my best to imply which character was having the birthday through framing and scenery props. Though it's not the best visual storytelling, Beowulf has the most contrast on values, the cake and the present box are closer to him, and I tried to put him closer to one of the two vertical lines of the thirds rule, although trying to avoid tangents messed this up a little.

After finishing my sketch, I decided to plan my values before painting. Since it was supposed to be an intimate and warm scene, I focused all the lights on the characters and left all the rest in darkness. It was also great to determinate how light or dark I wanted my lights and shadows to be. I must say that this was incredibly helpful later on!

Regarding colors, if I wanted a warm scene, I would have to use warm colors (I mean- that's not a rule, of course. But I can't think of another palette). I don't usually like to impose rules on myself while making art, but my palettes almost always ends up following the 60-30-10 rule. Overall, my palette is composed of:

Brownish and dark reds.

Dessaturated but contrastant greens.

And light and dessaturated yellows.

Wait- haven't I used this palette before...? Anyway...

One of my biggest challenges was dealing with dark colors. Usually I like a lot of variety in my colors, but as the color gets darker, the less varied it can get. To avoid that and also making my palette more coherent, I decided to paint with not so dark colors and then darken everything with multiply layers... Except it ended up destroying part of my color choices at the early stages... Blending modes are great, but it's really easy to lose track of your color choices while using them.

Right now one of my struggles is a kind of identity crisis within my painting style and sketching style. You see, I've always drawn more cartoonish and exaggerated expressions. But now that my painting style is more 'anatomically correct', the result ends up being uncanny. And so I always spend time in my painting process trying to fix the face... I should really do some studies.

Overall, although I was a little tight on the deadline, it was a really fun piece to make! Except the mirror, the whole process of painting, filtering, adding details and textures, etc was pretty enjoyable! Right now it's the most complex artwork I've made, and I'm pretty happy with it! :eggbug:

Hey! Thanks for reading once more!!!

See you soon,

-NekoRaita
